title: Elizabeth Plunket Greene
text:
Elizabeth Frances Plunket Greene (6 July 189918 December 1978) was an English crime novelist, writing in tandem with her husband, <a href="Richard%20Plunket%20Greene">Richard Plunket Greene</a>. She was part of the <a href="Bright%20Young%20Things">Bright Young Things</a> immortalized by <a href="Evelyn%20Waugh">Evelyn Waugh</a> in "<a href="Vile%20Bodies">Vile Bodies</a>" (mostly inspired by the Plunket Greenes).
Biography.
Elizabeth Frances Russell was born on 6 July 1899, the daughter of Harold John Hastings Russell and Lady Victoria Alberta Leveson-Gower. She was a granddaughter of <a href="Lord%20Arthur%20Russell">Lord Arthur Russell</a>, and second cousin once removed of <a href="Bertrand%20Russell">Bertrand Russell</a>. Her aunts were <a href="Flora%20Russell">Flora Russell</a> and <a href="Diana%20E.%20H.%20Russell">Diana Russell</a> and her great-grandmother was <a href="Diana%20Russell%2C%20Duchess%20of%20Bedford">Diana Russell, Duchess of Bedford</a>. Her family descended from <a href="Mary%20I%20of%20England">Mary I of England</a>.
While her fiancé, <a href="Richard%20Plunket%20Greene">Richard Plunket Greene</a>, was a school teacher at <a href="Aston%20Clinton">Aston Clinton</a>, Elizabeth Russell went to visit him and met <a href="Evelyn%20Waugh">Evelyn Waugh</a>, with whom she formed a friendship. Sometime she drove <a href="Alastair%20Hugh%20Graham">Alastair Hugh Graham</a>, who was Waugh's special friend of the time. It was the night of the party that Waugh and <a href="Olivia%20Plunket%20Greene">Olivia Plunket Greene</a>, Richard's sister and Waugh's love interest, had organised to celebrate Richard and Elizabeth's engagement, that Waugh and <a href="Matthew%20Ponsonby%2C%202nd%20Baron%20Ponsonby%20of%20Shulbrede">Matthew Ponsonby, 2nd Baron Ponsonby of Shulbrede</a>, Richard's cousin, were arrested while driving the wrong side in the Strand.
On 21 December 1926 Evelyn Waugh was a best man to the marriage of Elizabeth Frances Russell and Richard Plunket Greene. <a href="Patrick%20Balfour%2C%203rd%20Baron%20Kinross">Patrick Balfour, 3rd Baron Kinross</a> was a guest at the wedding. They had one son, <a href="Alexander%20Plunket%20Greene">Alexander Plunket Greene</a> (1932–1990), who married fashion designer <a href="Mary%20Quant">Mary Quant</a>. Plunket Greene and Russell divorced in 1943.
Together with her husband, in 1932, she wrote "Where Ignorance is Bliss", published with <a href="John%20Murray%20%28publishing%20house%29">John Murray</a>: "a murder story which is quite out of the beaten track." (Aberdeen Press). According to "<a href="The%20Punch">The Punch</a>": "It is not easy to strike an original note, but the Plunket Greenes have overcome the difficulty so emphatically that they may almost be accused of thumping." In 1934 they wrote "Eleven-Thirty Till Twelve", a detective novel set in London Society.
In the 1930s, Elizabeth Russell was a fan of motor racing and won a <a href="Grand%20Prix%20motor%20racing">grand prix</a> race in Belgium.
Elizabeth Plunket Greene died on 18 December 1978.
